constructs.name: Developer Experience Level
constructs.description: Baseline skill, years of professional experience, and accumulated problem-solving patterns in software development

constructs.name: Codebase Complexity
constructs.description: Overall architectural complexity, technical debt, and coupling of the system being worked on

constructs.name: Team Size
constructs.description: Number of available team members who can provide debugging support and guidance

constructs.name: Documentation Quality
constructs.description: Quality and availability of code documentation, architecture diagrams, and knowledge base resources

constructs.name: Tooling Quality
constructs.description: Quality of debugging tools, IDEs, logging infrastructure, and development environment

constructs.name: Error Information Quality
constructs.description: Quality of error messages, stack traces, and diagnostic logs that aid in root cause analysis

constructs.name: Testing Infrastructure Quality
constructs.description: Ability to reproduce errors, run tests, and verify fixes quickly through automated testing

constructs.name: Sleep Quality
constructs.description: Quality and duration of rest from prior night affecting next-day cognitive performance

constructs.name: Workload Volume
constructs.description: Amount of tasks, tickets, meetings, and responsibilities assigned on a given day

constructs.name: Interruption Frequency
constructs.description: How often deep work is broken by meetings, Slack messages, or other disruptions

constructs.name: Deadline Pressure
constructs.description: External time pressure from approaching deadlines, production incidents, or stakeholder demands

constructs.name: Error Complexity
constructs.description: Difficulty and intricacy of the specific errors being worked on including race conditions, edge cases, and integration issues

constructs.name: Cognitive Fatigue
constructs.description: Mental tiredness and depletion of cognitive resources affecting problem-solving and analytical ability

constructs.name: Stress Level
constructs.description: Psychological pressure, anxiety, and frustration related to work demands

constructs.name: Focus Quality
constructs.description: Ability to maintain sustained deep attention and concentration on debugging tasks

constructs.name: Code Familiarity
constructs.description: Developer's evolving knowledge and understanding of the specific code areas being debugged

constructs.name: Team Support Availability
constructs.description: Access to timely help and collaboration from team members for debugging assistance

constructs.name: Debugging Confidence
constructs.description: Self-efficacy and belief in ability to diagnose and resolve errors successfully

constructs.name: Systematic Debugging Behavior
constructs.description: Use of structured approaches like binary search, hypothesis testing, and incremental isolation versus random trial and error

constructs.name: Error Resolution Speed
constructs.description: How quickly errors and bugs are identified, diagnosed, and successfully fixed

edges.description: Experienced developers have better mental models and debugging heuristics built from years of pattern recognition
Experience builds stable self-efficacy in debugging abilities
Experienced developers have internalized systematic debugging methodologies
Complex, tightly-coupled systems produce harder-to-diagnose emergent errors
Complex codebases make errors harder to trace through layers of abstraction
Larger teams provide more potential sources of domain knowledge and debugging assistance
Good documentation helps understand expected behavior, system design, and known issues
Quality documentation accelerates learning about unfamiliar code areas
Better debuggers, IDE features, and profilers speed up error identification and root cause analysis
Good tools enable and encourage systematic debugging approaches like stepping through code
Clear error messages and detailed stack traces dramatically reduce diagnosis time
Ability to quickly write tests, reproduce errors, and verify fixes speeds the debug-fix-verify cycle
Poor sleep leads to higher baseline fatigue affecting next-day cognitive resources
Sleep deprivation directly impairs attention, working memory, and concentration
Heavy workloads deplete cognitive resources faster through the day
High workload creates pressure and increases perceived stress
High workload forces time-boxing on debugging, reducing thoroughness
Frequent interruptions break flow state and require costly context switching back to debugging
Context switching from interruptions is cognitively exhausting
Approaching deadlines amplify psychological pressure and anxiety
High pressure can cause abandonment of systematic approaches for desperate trial-and-error
Complex errors like race conditions or subtle memory issues require more time to diagnose and fix
Difficult errors increase frustration and pressure, especially under time constraints
Mental fatigue makes it progressively harder to maintain concentration
Fatigue impairs analytical reasoning and pattern recognition critical for debugging
Mental exhaustion reduces emotional regulation capacity increasing stress reactivity
High stress impairs working memory and sustained attention through rumination
Stress triggers reactive rather than deliberate debugging approaches
Sustained deep attention is critical for systematic debugging and holding complex state in working memory
Good focus enables methodical step-by-step debugging rather than scattered attempts
Knowing the code helps quickly locate and understand the source of errors
Familiarity with code increases confidence in ability to navigate and fix issues
Available teammates provide domain knowledge, pair debugging, and fresh perspectives
Knowing help is available reduces isolation and anxiety when stuck on hard bugs
Confidence enables persistent, systematic approaches rather than giving up or escalating prematurely
Confident developers trust systematic methods rather than flailing
Methodical approaches like binary search and hypothesis testing resolve errors faster than random attempts
Successfully resolving errors builds confidence and positive momentum for future debugging
Faster resolution reduces backlog pressure and frees mental bandwidth
Debugging teaches deep understanding of code behavior and edge cases

indicators.name: late_night_browsing
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if any browsing activity occurs between 00:00-05:00, 0 otherwise

indicators.name: morning_start_hour
indicators.how_to_measure: Record the hour (0-23) of the first browsing activity. Example: 9:35 AM returns 9. No activity = missing.

indicators.name: technical_entry_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count entries related to programming, debugging, or technical work. Include: programming languages, code, debug, error, github, stackoverflow, technical documentation, IDE, API.

indicators.name: distinct_work_topics
indicators.how_to_measure: Count distinct technical topic areas addressed (e.g., 'Haskell monads' = 1 topic, 'Ruby debugging' = 1 topic, 'API authentication' = 1 topic). Group similar/related searches as one topic.

indicators.name: topic_switch_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count transitions where consecutive entries cover clearly different topic domains (e.g., programming to food, technical to entertainment). Only count major domain changes.

indicators.name: work_gap_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count gaps greater than 15 minutes between consecutive work-related entries, suggesting interruption or distraction periods.

indicators.name: last_work_hour
indicators.how_to_measure: Record the hour (0-23) of the last technical/work-related entry of the day. No work entries = missing.

indicators.name: first_work_hour
indicators.how_to_measure: Record the hour (0-23) of the first technical/work-related entry of the day. No work entries = missing.

indicators.name: complex_debug_search_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches containing advanced debugging keywords: stacktrace, exception, race condition, deadlock, memory leak, segfault, concurrency, async error, thread safety, mutex, profiler

indicators.name: error_message_search_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches containing specific error messages, error codes, or exception class names (identifiable by quoted error text, numeric codes, or CamelCase exception patterns)

indicators.name: nonwork_entry_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count entries that are non-work related: entertainment, social media, news, personal interests, travel, food, shopping, music, games

indicators.name: afternoon_work_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count work-related entries occurring after 14:00 (2 PM). Fewer afternoon work entries relative to morning may indicate fatigue.

indicators.name: stress_health_search_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches related to: stress, anxiety, mental health, burnout, depression, sleep problems, relaxation, meditation, or mood-altering substances

indicators.name: escape_behavior_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count instances where entertainment/leisure entries appear immediately after work entries, suggesting escape-seeking behavior during work periods

indicators.name: work_clustering_rating
indicators.how_to_measure: Rate 1-5: How temporally clustered are work entries? 5 = tightly grouped with minimal time gaps, 1 = scattered throughout day. No work entries = 3.

indicators.name: max_consecutive_work_entries
indicators.how_to_measure: Count entries in the longest unbroken sequence of consecutive work entries (no leisure entries between them). No work entries = 0.

indicators.name: basic_lookup_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches for basic concepts or tutorials. Look for: 'what is X', 'how to X', 'X tutorial', 'X example', 'X for beginners', 'learn X', 'X basics'

indicators.name: documentation_visit_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to documentation or API reference sites. Identify by: docs, documentation, reference, API, wiki, manual in URL or title.

indicators.name: external_help_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to external Q&A sites: Stack Overflow, Reddit programming threads, GitHub issues/discussions, programming forums, dev.to

indicators.name: multi_site_same_query
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if same programming question is searched on multiple different external sites (suggesting exhaustive external search when team unavailable), 0 otherwise

indicators.name: debug_search_specificity
indicators.how_to_measure: Rate 1-5: How specific are debugging searches? 5 = very specific (exact function, precise error), 1 = vague ('help', 'not working'). No debugging searches = 3.

indicators.name: repeated_search_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count instances where very similar searches appear multiple times (same main keywords with minor variations), suggesting uncertainty

indicators.name: search_progression_rating
indicators.how_to_measure: Rate 1-5: How logical is the debugging search progression? 5 = clear steps (understand → narrow down → solve), 1 = random/scattered. No debugging = 3.

indicators.name: has_methodology_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if any search for debugging methodology ('debugging tips', 'how to debug', 'troubleshooting steps', 'debugging best practices'), 0 otherwise

indicators.name: debug_entry_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count entries about debugging/troubleshooting: error messages, 'debug', 'fix', 'solve', 'exception', 'troubleshoot', error codes

indicators.name: stuck_on_error
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if any specific error topic is searched 3+ times without apparent resolution (same error keywords recurring), 0 otherwise
